POSSIBLE MEASURES FOR AUGMENTING CARRYING CAPACITY " OF SKIPPING? Consideration has been given to the following suggested means of augmenting tonnage resources:1. Carrying of oil in double bottoms: Arrangements could be made for carrying oil in double bottoms, but the amount of oil which could be so carried without shutting out other cargo would be small and would contribute very little to the release of tankers for other purposes. Structural alterations would be necessary to make the double bottoms oil tight and to fit heating coils. In service, there would be further loss of time owing to deviations to pick up and discharge oil, and to the slow rate of working of the normal pumps available for loading and discharging oil. V/hen account is taken of the indirect reduction of tonnage through loss of time, it seems doubtful whether anything would be gained by this measure, unless the carrying of oil became a dominant requirement at the expense of and to the exclusion of other cargo. Records of suitable ships are, however, maintained and if circumstances changed, recourse could be had to this expedient for increasing the importation of oil. The agreement with the Norwegian shipowners, under which the Allies will secure 1^ million tons deadweight of Norwegian tankers on time charter, should make it unnecessary to incur, at any rate in the next few months, the disadvantages inseparable from this scheme. 2. Use of tankers for other cargoes: Tankers could be adapted for the carriage of grain, ore and coal, but the structural alterations necessary for this purpose would probably occupy three or four months, absorbing labour a^d materials. In the construction of new tankers under the Government programme, consideration is being given to the possibility of a type of construction which would render such conversion easier. The remaining vessels are now being required for trooping and other service and their cargo capacity, v/hich is very low in relation to their gross tonnage, will be utilised. The Lines will also use any available capacity in these ships for carrying certain types of cargo in suitable small packages. The conversion of lower deck passenger accommodation for the definite purpose of carrying cargo is being actively considered. 6* Use of ships now employed in the Great Lakes:. There are on the Canadian Great Lakes more than 100 ships of about 2 / 3 , 0 0 0 tons deadweight which were built in this country and made the voyage across under their own power. They present many technical difficulties and the vessels are unsuitable for use in Trans-Atlantic trade, and it may be that the Canadian Government would regard it as unsafe to contemplate even the single voyage in the v/inter; but the importance of obtaining the use of them for other purposes, even if it is necessary to wait until the spring, has been strongly urged upon our representatives in Canada. The replies and advice hitherto received have been disappointing but the matter is being pressed. The alternative possibility of the Lake vessels being used for Canadian coastwise traffic to release any suitable vessels for Trans-Atlantic voyages is also being investigated. 7 . Enquiries are also being made as to the possibility of buying a number of old cargo vessels from private American owners. It is possible that from both these sources about 50 vessels might be obtained at a cost of about 15 million dollars. 8* Transhipment cargo: In spite of the cost, delay and loss of ships1 time involved in transhipment? schemes of this kind should be investigated. Possible ports are Bergen (for vessels from the U.S.A.)? Lisbon or Oporto? and in particular, Alexandria or Port Said. Difficulties of storage will be serious. The use of Marseilles, where possible, on the basis of replacing? for French consumption, grain or other cargoes exported from North French ports, is to be preferred and is already being resorted to on a limited scale. 9 . Use of damaged ships now in Spain: There are a number of British ships which were sunk in Spanish harbours during the Civil war and are now held in Spain. Several of them (at least 6 ) are understood to have been raised and to be fit for service or worth repairing The Foreigh Office have for some time been pressing for their release. The Spanish Government, however, claim the right to bring them before a Prize Court and so far Foreign Office representations have not met with success.
